title: UK couple ‘ordered murder of adopted son to claim £150,000 in life insurance’
text:
Caption: Arti Dhir, 55, and Kaval Raijada, Gopal Sejani (Picture: Gujarat Police)

An airport worker and her husband are facing allegations they hired hitmen to murder their adopted son for a £150,000 insurance pay-out.

Arti Dhir, 55, and Kaval Raijada, 30, deny orchestrating the killings of Gopal Sejani and a relative who were stabbed in Gujarat.

Indian authorities believe she took out a policy on the orphan naming herself as sole beneficiary in the event of his death.

Details of the case emerged following an extradition hearing earlier this year.

The UK has so far refused requests to extradite the couple due to human rights concerns.

Gopal Sejani was allegedly murdered for an insurance pay-out

Arti Dhir is accused of plotting the murder of her adopted son (Picture: Gujarat Police)

Kaval Raijada is similar accused of conspiracy to murder (Picture: Gujarat Police)

According to the Daily Mail, Dhir, who came from Kenya as a child but now lives in west London, travelled to India with her husband to adopt Gohal after placing an advert in a local paper.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Gopal was told his ‘life would be improved’ in the UK and Indian authorities reportedly claim the pair immediately took out a life insurance policy in his name, paying two premiums totalling £30,000 in anticipation of a £150,000 pay-out in the event of his death.

But the youngster never arrived in the UK.

He was abducted while the adoption was being finalised in February 2017 and stabbed during the ambush, along with his brother-in-law, Harsukh Kardani, who was looking after him at the time.

It is also claimed that there were two previous failed attempts to kill the boy, the paper reports.

The insurance policy never paid out.

Dhir and Raijada face charges including conspiracy to murder and kidnapping.

They were arrested in the UK in June 2017 following a request by the Indian authorities and a number of extradition hearings have taken place this year.

Chief Magistrate Emma Arbuthnot said at the latest hearing that on the face of it there appeared to be sufficient evidence, but refused to grant extradition because a potential life sentence without parole would be ‘inhuman and degrading’.

The Indian government has appealed the decision.
